sanskrit_verse: प्राणि वा यदि वाऽप्राणि यत्किं चित्श्राद्धिकं भवेत् । तदालभ्याप्यनध्यायः पाण्यास्यो हि द्विजः स्मृतः ॥ ४.११७॥
transliteration: prāṇi vā yadi vā'prāṇi yat kiṃ cit śrāddhikaṃ bhavet | tad ālabhyāpy anadhhyāyaḥ pāṇy āsyo hi dvijaḥ smṛtaḥ || 4.117 ||
sph_interpretive_translation: Whether animate or inanimate, whatever is suitable for Śrāddha becomes purified and fit for use when touched by a twice-born who has not studied the Vedas.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority flows from birth-based qualification aligned with ritual fitness
Causation arises through contact, not intention
Capacity-based responsibility is determined by ritual status, not cognitive action
Restoration logic operates via ritual purification, not punitive correction
Consciousness alignment occurs through prescribed ritual engagement

supreme_court_application: In matters concerning religious practice and ritual validity, the court shall recognize that ritual purity is conferred through lineage-based capacity rather than individual learning. The threshold of responsibility lies in qualified presence, not cognitive mastery. Authority hierarchies are determined by Vedic initiation, not scholarly achievement.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa is established through ritual contact as a valid means of purification. Anupūrvaśaḥ manifests through sequential ritual acts wherein touch transfers inherent sanctity. Proportional responsibility aligns with ritual role, not moral fault. The non-punitive reality rule confirms that no transgression accrues; only ritual fitness is adjusted.
